This guide provides procedures to install the Blue Planet Multi-Domain Service Orchestration (MDSO) and Network Virtual Function Orchestration (NFVO) platform and solutions in a single-host or multi-host deployment in Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Microsoft Azure. The supported OS versions are RHEL 7.8, CentOS 7.8 and Ubuntu 16.04.06

MDSO/NFVO installation workflow involves spinning up AWS EC2 instance(s) or Azure VM(s), OS-level configurations and product installation process. Review the following guidelines and OS configuration requirements before you begin installation:
Blue Planet MDSO/NFVO installation files, users, requirements, and procedures are described in the following topics:
The Blue Planet Orchestration (MDSO/NFVO) cloud hosted deployment requires:

content.text: In order for HA to function properly, it is required that:
At least three nodes exist in the cluster so that in case of a failure, remaining nodes can identify a leader and can maintain a quorum while continuing to provide service.

Table 3 shows the recommended server disk space allocations based on total disk space recommended in Table 2. Mount the file systems with the standard options. However, /home must allow the MDSO/NFVO BPI installer to execute.
Table 4. Recommended MDSO/NFVO server disk space allocations
Logging from applications and services to syslog
Scales based on number of MDSO/NFVO domains, services, resources, events, and other entities
(defaults to the unallocated disk space in the root volume group)
The ports listed in the following table must be open to allow communication among MDSO/NFVO hosts and components. Ports include:
DNS client—Allows the Blue Planet server to resolve names.
DHCP client (optional)—Allows the Blue Planet server to get IP addresses through DHCP.
NTP client—Used to set the time on the Blue Planet server.
SNMP server—Used for Blue Planet server monitoring.
SSH server—Used for Blue Planet server administrative access.
Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) tunnel between hosts. For host-to-host connectivity over GRE, IP connectivity must be available. TCP or UDP ports are not required.
Complete this procedure to download the files needed to install the Blue Planet Orchestration:
While LinuxIntel_2020_34_0. and bpi-8.0-24.sh are the current versions, later versions might be available at the time you download the file. If so, use the later version.
Download the installation files on a computer separate from the MDSO/NFVO host. Do not transfer them to the MDSO/NFVO host until instructed to do so.
Blue Planet supports Microsoft Azure and Amazon AWS for cloud hosted deployments.
The AWS and Azure images can be of the following types:
If you are deploying the Blue Planet Orchestration (BPO) using an marketplace image or golden image, you would need to install OS, configure OS, create users, and configure disks.
In case of Blue Planet base image, OS is already installed and configured. Based upon your preference, select the required procedure:
Contact your Ciena account representative if you have questions about license server requirements.

To install Blue Planet MDSO/NFVO, perform the following procedures on host 0 in sequence. For multihost installations, you need to repeat these procedures on other hosts.
The following table provides an overview to the installation procedures, where you perform them, and key notes.

Complete the following procedure to create the bpadmin user on each host where you will install the MDSO/NFVO. The bpadmin user is given full passwordless sudo privileges. For multi-host installations, use the same bpadmin password on all hosts. The bpadmin user with full sudo access is needed to install the MDSO/NFVO applications and to create the bpuser, which has limited sudo access.
You must have a password that you want to assign for the bpadmin user.

Is the directory of the bpadmin user. Set /home/bpadmin as the bpadmin user home directory. If you use another directory, adapt the steps through the MDSO/NFVO installation to point to that directory, as required.
Set the password for the bpadmin user:
For multi-host deployments, repeat this procedure on each host. Use the same bpadmin password on all hosts.
After you complete the MDSO/NFVO installation, you can optionally delete the bpadmin user and use bpuser for ongoing Docker, solman, and bp2-site operations.

Swappiness is the kernel parameter that defines how much and how frequently your Linux kernel copies RAM contents to swap. The higher the swappiness parameter, the more aggressively your kernel will swap. Ciena recommends that you set the kernel swappiness value for each MDSO/NFVO host to 10.
For multi-host installations, complete steps 1-4 at each host.
Use this procedure to disable SELinux and firewalld.

A LinuxIntel_2020_13.0 (or later) directory is created.

root# lsblk NAME MAJ:MIN RM SIZE RO TYPE MOUNTPOINT nvme0n1 259:1 0 50G 0 disk \u2514\u2500nvme0n1p1 259:2 0 50G 0 part / nvme1n1 259:0 0 1.2T 0 disk The following output displays for Azure:

In the above output, nvme1n1 and sdc are the second 1.2 TB storage volume in AWS and Azure, respectively

content.text: It adds the host(s) where you want to install the MDSO/NFVO to the hosts file. The MDSO/NFVO installer uses the host file entries to perform the MDSO/NFVO installation. This is required for all installations.
host0 ansible_host=10.187.0.1 controller=True host1 ansible_host=10.187.0.2 controller=True host2 ansible_host=10.187.0.3 controller=True

header: Change the ILAN tunnel type (Azure cloud only)

content.text: For Blue Planet multi-host sites in the Azure Cloud, complete this procedure to change the ILAN tunnel type to Vxlan.
content.header: Change the ILAN tunnel type (Azure cloud only)

content.text: # Valid options for ilan_tunnel_type are gre or vxlan. Default is gre.
The following shows an example after the edit:
# Valid options for ilan_tunnel_type are gre or vxlan. Default is gre.

Complete the following steps to modify the volume group name where the unallocated physical extents space is left free for MDSO/NFVO to create and configure the Docker thin pool. The volume group name is important because it might be used to restore data on another system. Ciena recommends using unique names that can be recognized and avoid name conflicts across multiple virtual groups.

This procedure is the first of five procedures requiring edits to the all.yml file located in the /home/bpadmin/bpi/playbooks/group_vars directory. Most of the edits are "as required" by your specific network environment and MDSO/NFVO installation. You might not need complete many of them unless you want to change the default values.
Before you begin this procedure, verify that you:

This procedure configures the Network Time Protocol (NTP) server(s) to serve as the timing source for MDSO/NFVO hosts. This is a mandatory procedure. All MDSO/NFVO hosts must be synchronized to an accurate timing source.
MDSO/NFVO hosts can use a local or remote time source. For example:
By default, the MDSO/NFVO installer sets up four NTP servers:

While you can specify your own NTP servers, or use fewer servers, Ciena recommends that you always have a minimum of three—and preferably four—timing servers for optimal MDSO/NFVO timing synchronization. The number of upstream servers, in order of most to least preferred, is given below.
Disable all other timing synchronization methods including, but not limited to, VMware Tools periodic time synchronization.
Following installation, you can use the bp2-site check-platform or bp2-site check-clock-
Before you begin this procedure, verify that you:
If you want to use a local time source or custom remote time sources (different than the default ones provided), then perform this procedure.
# By default, NTP will be configured if the number of hosts listed in the hosts file is > 1.
# There are 2 options 'remote' (default) and 'local'. The default configuration (remote) will set up NTP to connect
# to a set of remote, Operating System specific, servers. If local is specified, host0 will be used as the ntp clock
# reference for all nodes in the cluster. This is controlled via the 'ntp_server_type' outlined below. #

######## ## NTP # By default, NTP will be configured if the number of hosts listed in the hosts file is > 1. # There are 2 options 'remote' (default) and 'local'. The default configuration (remote) will set up NTP to connect # to a set of remote, Operating System specific, servers. If local is specified, host0 will be used as the ntp clock # reference for all nodes in the cluster. This is controlled via the 'ntp_server_type' outlined below. #
# In the 'remote' case, you can also override the set of remote servers by uncommenting and setting the
# 'ntp_servers_custom' variable and configuring 1,3 or 4 NTP servers to connect to.
# In the 'remote' case, you can also override the set of remote servers by uncommenting and setting the
# 'ntp_servers_custom' variable and configuring 1,3 or 4 NTP servers to connect to.
Uncomment the following lines, replace <host a> with your own NTP server IP. Use 169.254.169.123 for Ciena VPC account.

header: Configuring the Blue Planet email service

content.text: MDSO/NFVO requires that you configure a Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) server so MDSO/NFVO can send system email to users. Emails are used for alarm notifications and forgotten password assistance.
content.header: Configuring the Blue Planet email service

content.text: Before you begin this procedure, verify that you:
The SMTP server account username used for sending emails.
The staticPath value must be /bp2/src/static. Do not change this value.
The SMTP server authentication. Set the value to true.
The SMTP server transport security. Set the value to true or false, as applicable.
The SMTP server fully qualified domain name (FQDN), such as smtp.gmail.com or, if a dedicated SMTP server, an FQDN that you own.
Must be set to Blue Planet Mailer. Do not change this value.
The SMTP server port number. Depending on the server, this port can be 25, 465, or 587.

The SMTP server email account from which reset password emails will be sent. Some SMTP servers, such as Gmail, allow you to use an alias that is not set on the server. For example, the account could be "bphostmonitor@abccompany.com", but the value could be "api-crinoid@ciena.com". Of course, you can enter the true value, "bphostmonitor@abccompany.com". The Amazon Web Services (AWS) SMTP server restricts the entry to the correct value.
# SMTP configuration details for 'Forgot Password' feature

# SMTP configuration details for 'Forgot Password' feature smtp_username: GmailUser smtp_password: AnyPassword smtp_staticPath: /bp2/src/static smtp_authen: true smtp_transport: true smtp_mail_server: smtp.gmail.com smtp_mailer_name: Blue Planet Mailer smtp_port: 587 smtp_email: api-crinoid@AnyCompany.com
MDSO/NFVO uses the address, 172.16.0.0/16/24, for its internal LAN (iLAN). Complete this procedure if:
Your network already uses 172.16.0.0/16/24, in which case, a conflict with the MDSO/NFVO iLAN will occur.
Before you begin this procedure, verify that you:

header: Configuring floating private IP for Azure

content.text: The floating ip mechanism for Azure operates by adding or removing IP configurations in the Network interface card of the Azure virtual machines.
